data.title: Fix release channel detection on Travis
data.body:
Fixes #12571 

In the previous build scripts, we were considering all the builds triggered by a pull-request to be part of the dev channel. We adopted the same heuristic for the new build scripts, but didn't notice that Travis always sets the `TRAVIS_PULL_REQUEST` variable to "false" (which causes the `process.env.TRAVIS_PULL_REQUEST` expression to be evaluated as truthy).

In the past, this wasn't a problem because we were building artifacts via Janky, but after switching to Travis this makes it generate the wrong assets on stable and beta.

To fix this, it seems reasonable to remove the conditional that checks if we are building a pull-request: in the past this could have been problematic because assets could be uploaded inadvertently to S3 or GitHub, but this should be safe now that we rely on the release publisher to perform that task.

/cc: @nathansobo @joefitzgerald

data.title: Atom does not load correctly with VirtualBox Guest Additions installed
data.body:
### Prerequisites
- [y] Can you reproduce the problem in [safe mode](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#using-safe-mode)?
- [y] Are you running the [latest version of Atom](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/#update-to-the-latest-version)?
- [y] Did you check the [debugging guide](http://flight-manual.atom.io/hacking-atom/sections/debugging/)?
- [y] Did you check the [FAQs on Discuss](https://discuss.atom.io/c/faq)?
- [y] Are you reporting to the [correct repository](https://github.com/atom/atom/blob/master/CONTRIBUTING.md#atom-and-packages)?
- [y] Did you [perform a cursory search](https://github.com/issues?q=is%3Aissue+user%3Aatom+-repo%3Aatom%2Felectron) to see if your bug or enhancement is already reported?
### Description

Atom and VirtualBox Guest Additions are both installed in the /opt directory. If I remove guest additions, atom opens and loads just fine. However, if I install guest additions and then reboot, atom opens, but does not load/render correctly. It opens but only has a black/gray pixelated window and is unusable. As soon as I remove the guest additions directory, Atom opens and loads perfectly. I have tested this in safe mode as well.

Installing Atom from the Ubuntu repo (which installs version 1.0.11) works perfect with guest additions installed. In order to install the newest version of Atom, I have to remove the /opt directory to avoid the warnings that Atom couldn't install properly, then reinstall Atom, and then reinstall guest additions, in which case Atom no longer loads/renders correctly. I also tried to install Atom using the webupd8/atom ppa, and have the same issues. 
### Steps to Reproduce
1. Install Atom
2. Install Guest Additions
3. Reboot
4. Start Atom
### Versions

OS (Guest): Bodhi 3.2.1 (Ubuntu 14.04)
VirtualBox Guest Additions 5.1.4
Atom 1.9.9

data.title: Atom GUI corrupted when run in VirtualBox within LinuxMint guest
data.body:
Should be simple to reproduce:
- Create LinuxMint 17.3 (tried KDE) or 18 (tried Cinnamon) guest in VirtualBox (v.5.1.4)
- Make sure equal version of VirtualBox guest additions are installed
- Install any version of Atom greater than 1.8 (1.8 does not exhibit the error), including 1.11.0-beta0
- Start Atom

You should see the mostly-blank/corrupted GUI upon startup.
This also happens in safe mode.
This appears to happen whether the host is Windows (tried Win 7 Pro) or Linux (tried Linux Mint 17.3 KDE)

data.title: Simplify Environment Patching
data.body:
This PR simplifies the logic used to determine when to patch the environment for users of linux and macOS. Instead of using a whitelist of shells and trying to detect how Atom was launched with environment variable markers, we simply modify `atom.sh` to set a environment variable that is only set when launched from the shell. If this environment variable is not detected, the environment is patched with the environment from a new, interactive, login shell.
- [x] Stop whitelisting shells
- [x] Introduce `ATOM_SUPPRESS_ENV_PATCHING` environment variable, which is only set in `atom.sh`
- [x] Manually test on Ubuntu
- [x] Manually test on macOS

Fixes #11910
Fixes #12535

data.title: Fix show/hide line numbers in editor
Use the correct Atom executable paths on the beta channel
data.body: In #12410 we started using electron-packager which automatically renames Electron executables (e.g. `Electron Helper`, `Contents/MacOS/Electron`) to match the provided app name. This behavior differs from the previous Grunt-based scripts and caused breakage in places where we assumed these executables would always be named `Atom`.

data.title: Allow to run script/build --install on all platforms
data.body:
Fixes #12549.

This pull-request adds the ability to run `script/build --install` also on Linux (installing Atom in `/usr/local`) and on Windows (installing Atom in `C:\Users\<user name>\AppData\Local\`).

/cc: @nathansobo

data.title: Always copy item when splitting from the context menu
data.body:
This updates the context menu so that splitting behaves consistently, regardless of whether the context menu is used from a text editor or not.

The current behavior comes from #7953 but, as @maxbrunsfeld pointed out when we talked about this, the purpose of that commit was to simplify the command names, so the UX change probably wasn't intentional.

data.title: Run script/bootstrap from script/build
data.body:
This is how things worked previously, and it seems both convenient and low-cost. In the [Scripts To Rule Them All](https://github.com/github/scripts-to-rule-them-all) standard, there are examples of [scripts calling other scripts](https://github.com/github/scripts-to-rule-them-all/blob/master/script/test#L20).

/cc @as-cii @lee-dohm

data.title: script/build  --install fails with "Cannot read property 'getCachePath' of undefined"
data.body:
The new build system, for me, eecf830, is acting up.

I can't get the build to complete.  I'm on Slackware, and have been happily building from sources for many months.  No more joy as of an hour or two ago.

getCachePath seems the guilty identifier that blows things up.

